item.title: 2023 Memorable Content
item.description: Like most overly-online folks of my generation, I read and watch and listen to a lot of content practically every day of every week.
item.content:encoded:
Like most overly-online folks of my generation, I read and watch and listen to a lot of content practically every day of every week. Articles, blogs, podcasts, YouTube, news/debates/interviews/more. This was true this year, as it has been for maybe a decade now. This year though, I made a constant effort to collate anything that crossed the no-man's-land of mild interest, so I might look at a full retrospective on the select media content that got into hand-to-hand combat with existing precepts I held, or lit the path for questions I was just beginning to understand.

So yes, this is just another "Best Of" list. But it's my Best Of List, and I like it quite a bit. So here are some of my favorite blog posts, tech talks, interviews, and other reads/listens from 2023. Excepting the final section, all these links are for material released in the year 2023.

The most significant recurring topic pertains to software engineering and machine learning, but others include zero-day attacks, gender dynamics, free speech, and more. I annotated these visually as Software, ML, Cyber, Gender, Speech & Media, and Other.

Best From 2023â€‹

ğŸ“ How Discord Stores Trillions of Messages

Software by Bo Ingram. Fantastic nitty-gritty details on scaling in production. Bonus points for the occasional dry humor!

ğŸ“ Handling a Regional Outage: Comparing the Response From AWS, Azure and GCP

Software by Gergely Orosz. If you have any work involving cloud providers then this is an absolute must read. The final grades are not the key takeaway for me; rather it's fascinating to see the range of possible outages and responses.

ğŸ“ Measuring developer productivity? A response to McKinsey

Software by Gergely Orosz. A better effort than any scrum discussion or blog post in order to conceptualize what work actually gets done, how do we measure it, and how does our measuring system cause feedback into the work itself.

ğŸ“ How Scale Kills Data Teams

Software ML by Chad Sanderson. Data contracts are an interesting solution to a frequent, almost ever-present problem. While I still haven't gotten to apply the concept at work, this blog post gives a very relatable picture of the underlying problem.

ğŸ“ Unlocking Real-time Predictions with Shopify's Machine Learning Platform

Software ML by Isaac Vidas. A from-the-ground-up tour of a new in-house ML platform. Interesting to me, having only worked with KubeFlow before for MLops.

ğŸ“ Lessons From Linguistics: i18n Best Practices for Front-End Developers

Software by Lucas Huang. A simple explanation of the varying challenges for i18n, and much more approachable than reading about a full i18n/l10n solution like GNU gettext for the first time. Also scratches my linguistic itch to revisit cross-language variance in syntax.

ğŸ“ Visual Anagrams: Generating Multi-View Optical Illusions with Diffusion Models

Software ML by Daniel Geng, Inbum Park, Andrew Owens. Even a quick glance is impressive, just take a look!

ğŸ“ The Dangers of Googleâ€™s .zip TLD

Cyber by Bobbyr. The .zip domain was a controversial Twitter-storm, but this was a standalone example of the clever application to phishing attacks, and is very quick to read through and understand.

ğŸ“ Warriors Wanted and

ğŸ“ The Boys Who Surf Subways

Gender by Olivia Reingold and McCaffrey Blauner. An interesting pair of articles, about problems and solutions to the quiet crisis of masculinity. For a deeper look at the topic, consider Richard Reeves' book, Of Boys and Men.

ğŸ“º The Economics of Programming Languages

Software by Evan Czaplicki. By far my favorite tech talk of the year. Economics, PL theory, dev drama, dunking on big tech companies, Georgism, wow it's a complex and fun picture that gets woven together here.

ğŸ“º Pydantic is all you need

Software ML by Jason Liu. This was a paradigm shift, where I now can see how LLMs are ready at the implementation level for prime-time product use (at least in low-stakes applications), with structured and reliable output.

ğŸ“º Router vulnerability discovery and

ğŸ“º exploiting for remote command execution

Cyber by the Flashback team. A fun whirlwind of exploit discovery and development. Do you believe that your router can be rooted just by receiving a malformed DNS request? This talk will help illustrate how, and more generally what zero-days in critical infrastructure can look like!

ğŸ“º Premature Optimization

Software by CodeAesthetic. I feel this sentiment so strongly. Enough said.

ğŸ“º Training Your Own AI Model

Software ML by Steve from Builder.io. A succinct summary of when smaller, proprietary AI models can be the right choice.

ğŸ“º Ethical Hacking: What is "Ethical?"

Cyber by John Hammond and LiverOverflow. The cyber security community has quietly converged on healthy norms of openness and collaboration for handling exploits, but those boundaries always can evolve (either in response to new tech, like LLMs for phishing, or new incentives, like ransomware for financial gain). This long-form conversation between two experts is the type of well-informed, good-faith discussion that pushes professional norms in the right direction, and it's fun to listen in detail.

ğŸ“º Has the Sexual Revolution Failed?

Gender by The Free Press. Not an issue I'd thought about as requiring debate, but all four debaters had thought-provoking remarks to share.

ğŸ§ The Book I Wish Every Policymaker Would Read

Other from the Ezra Klein podcast. The fundamentals for why the U.S. government is currently incentivized against delivering on politically viable commitments.

ğŸ§ The Most Amazing â€” and Dangerous â€” Technology in the World

Other from the Ezra Klein podcast. Semiconductor technology is a true marvel, and the impact of the technology (as well as its unique market) now affects all sectors, from economics, to geopolitics, to AI, to industrial policy, and more.

ğŸ§ Social Media & Public Trust

Speech & Media from the Making Sense podcast, with Sam Harris. A concise and from-the-source retelling of what was discovered in the Twitter Files reporting. Sam Harris is well-positioned as a critical (and at times, oppositional) interviewer on this topic.

ğŸ§ Tobi Lutke & Kaz Nejatian on Shopify's Country-Sized Economy

Other from the Network State Podcast podcast. A great understanding of how one of the quietest big tech companies thinks about their economic mission and impact.

ğŸ§ The Private Equity Debate Revisited

Other from the Capitalisn't podcast.

ğŸ§ Tim Urban on Everything

Speech & Media Other from the Good Fight, with Yascha Mounk. Tim Urban is one of the best "explainers" of just about any topic he touches, and this interview is an interesting redux of previous topics, and how they fit into his recently released book, What's Our Problem.

ğŸ§ Greg Lukianoff on Cancel Culture, Deplatforming, Censorship & Free Speech

Speech & Media from the Lex Fridman podcast. FIRE has been doing critical work for decades now, and receives deserved praise for the massively increasing scope over the past few years.

ğŸ§ Jimmy Wales on Wikipedia

Speech & Media from the Lex Fridman podcast. Fun to hear the full perspective on how Wikipedia is run, and its evolving place in our information ecosystem.

ğŸ§ Money Doomscape of the Debt Apocalypse

Other from the Political Orphanage podcast, with Andrew Heaton. An earnest historical primer on how the U.S. debt has come about, and why the system is the way it is. (With a fun, if mostly unrelated, historical anecdote to kick things off!)

ğŸ§ The Longest Happiness Study in History

Other from the Political Orphanage podcast, with Andrew Heaton. What makes humans happy? Hear from Dr. Robert Waldinger and you might know just a little bit more.

ğŸ§ Sim City Was Always Wrong

Other from the Political Orphanage podcast, with Andrew Heaton. Alain Bertaud is a brilliant voice to listen to if you've ever wondered "why," about those qualities of your city that you deem esteemable or disagreeable.

ğŸ§ Why Men Seek Danger

Gender from Honestly, with Bari Weiss. One more perspective on how we can conceive of male gender dynamics in our modern age.

ğŸ§ Why 65% of Fourth Graders Can't Really Read

Other from Honestly, with Bari Weiss. Everyone cares about literacy, because everyone deserves an on-ramp to the opportunities that depend on it. It is shocking and disappointing that such a critical topic has quietly been taken over with tribally-motivated thinking, and real humans have to face the consquences.

Older Stuff, Newly Readâ€‹

Finally, here is some more content that might be less topical, but still interested me this year when I encountered it for the first time.

ğŸ“º Are You Eating a Credit Card Every Week?

Speech & Media by vlogbrothers. A vital reality check on how poorly our information ecosystem sometimes behaves.

ğŸ“º The Future of Programming

Software by Bret Victor. A very fun, self-aware tour of paradigmatic assumptions deeply baked into the modern field of computer science and software engineering.

ğŸ“– My Pilgrimage to Nonviolence

Other by Martin Luther King Jr. I've reminded myself to read at least one new King essay for several years in a row now, and this one is a wonderful epistemological tour of King's thinking and influences.

ğŸ“ Fast

Other by Patrick Collison. These examples provide an important reminder for the feasibility of immediate progress.

ğŸ“ Rooms and Mazes: A Procedural Dungeon Generator

Software by Bob Nystrom. Visual, fun, and oddly simple in it's apparent complexity.

ğŸ“ The Door Problem

Other by Liz England. A clear explanation for how to think about software interactions, almost like pragmatics as per linguistics.

ğŸ“ The Law of Leaky Abstractions

Software by Joel Spolsky. Abstractions are a fundamental concept for the layers of software in every project and stack, and have the untold benefits of not "re-building the wheel" each time. But they come with consequences or limitations; as a developer I had observed many times when an abstraction was too "brittle" for certain changes, but Joel Spolsky puts together an even clearer picture of what it means for an abstraction to be more generally "leaky."

ğŸ“– A Deepness in the Sky

Other by Vernor Vinge. Vinge continues to be one of my all-time favorite authors. The novelty of his xenobiological and his technological descriptions together make each novel a truly unique delight.

ğŸ“– Project Hail Mary

Other by Andy Weir. Another tale of satisfying multi-displinary competency in engineering, but even farther reaching in scope and scale than in The Martian.

ğŸ“– How Adam Smith Can Change Your Life

Other by Russ Roberts. Through Adam Smith's writings and thoughts, this puts words to multiple observations I had bumped into but never had the awareness to concretely frame. Not as immediately applicable as some "self help" books, but it doesn't claim to be. Adam Smith's conception of the good life is a long term perspective I've enjoyed thinking about.

ğŸ“– Babylon's Ashes and

ğŸ“– Persepolis Rising and

ğŸ“– Tiamat's Wrath

Other by James S.A. Corey. Space Opera go boom :D But in seriousness, The Expanse has not disappointed as the series draws to its conclusion. It has far outgrown the "Game-of-Thrones-in-space" comparison, and deservedly now defines its own scifi lodestone with the carefully-grounded technology and interstellar world building, the beautiful multi-plotline tension built into every book's climax, and the finally unveiling plot destination for the series.

item.title: 10 minute moments
item.content:encoded:
16 waking hours Ã· 10 minutes = 96

10 minutes is ~1% of your day.

- by Taylor Troesh

When the phone scrolling lasts for 10 minutes, or low-priority yak shaving tasks draw your attention for 10 minutes, that's one percent of your day spent. That's not necessarily a bad thing or a good thing, but make sure it's a thing you want to spend one percent of your day on.

You only have this many of those 10 minute moments.

Many minutes, but few moments.
